transcript.content: Shawn Gaspard Transcription REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I'm Shawn Gaspard. I was 24 years old. I was convicted of First Degree Murder. Doing a life sentence.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And how much time have you served, Shawn?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: 24 years and 10 months.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I'm going to start by asking a few questions about your childhood, your time before that. Can you tell me a little bit about the folks who raised you?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: It was my mother and stepdad.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about them.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Well, my stepdad was a real heavy drinker and my mother, all she did was work in bars so.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you find yourself butting heads with your stepdad?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: No, not too often.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How old were you when he came into your life?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: A baby.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. What's your last memory of interacting with him?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: My last memory. My mother kicked me out the house and he let me go stay with him for a day or a night. And he brought me back to Lafayette, and just drooped me back off at my mother's house.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so they were split up at that point?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Well, then again, they do, he did come visit a few times up here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, they're no longer together?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Oh no. Well, he passed away years and years ago.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh okay. Alright. What about your mom? Tell me about your mother.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: My mother. Like I said she was, she was a bartender all her life. So...

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: In Lafayette?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When was the last time you saw her?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I guess the October rodeo. Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Does she come and visit you very frequently?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Not anymore. She's having lung problems.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: So.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Do you have siblings?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Oh, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about them.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I got two brothers and two sisters.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do they visit you here?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: When I call and ask them to come see me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Does anybody else visit you?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I got an aunt. I got an uncle that comes sometimes. And a friend of mine every once in a while. We grew up together.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Would it be fair to say you were raised in a loving, caring household or not?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: That I don't know cause I don't have nothing to judge off somebody else to say, "Oh yeah, it was loving." But I don't believe it was cause, once my mother and father, stepdad, divorced, it was just my mother, she was always working. So it was, it was just me, my sister, and two brothers. My older sister was already out of the house and all that. So, it was just kind of raising ourselves, I guess.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Where are you in the birth order?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I'm the second, the second to oldest.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, did you have the responsibility of taking care of your younger siblings? Did you feel that?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: At the time, not really. I didn't, I mean. I didn't have no responsibility saying to myself that my mother needs my help to raise them. No, it wasn't nothing like that. We was all, we was all running the roads all the time. So.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I wasn't going see where my sister was, or where my brother was because I was doing the same thing, running the roads,

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Hanging out with friends. Going out every night.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Can you paint a picture for me? I've visited Lafayette a few times, but if I was in your neighborhood, where you grew up, your mom's house, if I was sitting on the stoop or the front porch looking out on a typical day, what would it look like?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Well, we lived in condominiums.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh, okay.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: It was a condominium, so it was a whole bunch of condominium apartment complexes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I guess if you, I guess if you were standing on the sidewalk, looking out, you'd see another apartment complex. That's what it was, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: All right, was it in downtown Lafayette?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. What about school? Do you have some specific memories from school? Did you like school?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Not really. I had a little girlfriend. I mean, I had friends. Was like, I was going to class. I wasn't learning. I mean, I wasn't participating, I wasn't taking things home and trying to learn, or do education. Do educational work. I was just going to school, that's all.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you finish school?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I got a GED.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, was that before Angola?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah, in the Parish.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh, okay, in the Parish Prison.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, what was the highest grade you competed before that?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Ninth or tenth. Somewhere around there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. What's your fondest memory of school?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Fondest memory of school. I guess, just being with my little girlfriend I guess.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about her.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: My little girlfriend? She was Iranian. Real nice people. As a matter of fact, she the one that actually, I had already quit school and she had told me to come back to school. So, I went back to school for a little while, but that was just to hang out with her. That's all.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What was her name?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Ellie.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Ellie? Are you still in contact with her?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: No. I mean, we were 17 years old.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Any other women in your life before coming here?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Man, I lived with a woman. I had a bunch of, I ain't going to say girlfriends, but I mean, I had women that, occupied my time every once in a while.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: But other than that, like I said, I had no sense of direction. I was just, a friend of mine would go out sometimes, or me and a little girl would go out sometimes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Did I have a job? I bounced. I had some really decent jobs but I just kind of, I'm going to say pissed them away. I wasn't motivated to get a job, have an apartment, start pay bills, wasn't nothing like that. It was just, like I said, I was young.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. What was the best job that you had?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Best job, probably offshore, I guess. Best paying job anyway.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What were you doing?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I was just a galley hand, cleaning up, do the dishes,.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about children? Do you have children?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: No, I don't have children.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You mentioned that you were kind of left to your own devices as a child –

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: As an adolescent

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Was there much fighting in the house?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Not too often.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, what about outside the house?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I had my share of fights.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What were they about?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Oh, just, I don't know, boy stuff. I mean we just...

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I understand.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: We didn't like each other. Instead of going our separate ways, we'd just fight each other.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Were you ever kicked out of school?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Oh yeah, once.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What was that for?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I think fighting.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember the first time you were arrested?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What was that about?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Shoplifting.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How old were you?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: 17? Yeah, 17. I was going steal some little music tapes and I had a cousin, well, I got a cousin, she wanted me, she asked me if I was going shoplifting. I told her yeah and she said, "Well if you can, can you get me this tape?" And she went with me. But she stayed outside, and when I got busted, she went home and took a bunch of pills and tried to kill herself.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember what the tape was?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: No, I don't remember the tape.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Were you close with that cousin?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: My cousin. She still, she wants to come visit me now as a matter of fact. I mean, we alright. We don't stay in touch too much, but we okay. That's my aunt's daughter.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about drugs and alcohol? Were drugs and alcohol apart of your life?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I've had my share of them.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah? Were they in any way related what got you here?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: This murder charge? Actually, I was doing some heavy drinking but I had stopped drinking a couple weeks before this ever happened.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. Can you tell me a little bit about what lead you down this wrong road?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Like I said, no sense of direction. I didn't have no responsibility to say I need to do this. I need to do that. I was just, just running the roads, like I said. Whatever came, if I had a little job, great? If I had a little money, I would stay from friends to friend's houses sometimes. Just going out every night.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: If you had to isolate one main reason that this happened, what would it be?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Hanging out with somebody that I should have never been hanging out with.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. Wrong place, wrong time? Wrong person?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Wrong person, right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: If somebody were to ask you if you were mistreated as a child, would you say yes or no?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I'm going to say not really. I got whipped whenever I did something wrong. I mean, me and my momma didn't get along too much. I mean, she'd kick me out the house all the time. But, did I deserve it? Probably. Probably on some instances, I'd say that I did deserve it sometimes. Sometimes, maybe she was going through menopause, I don't know.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So one of the reasons we wanted to talk with you is that you are now, 25 years on, you are considered a trusted, rehabilitated member with this community.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I would hope I am.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, I want to try and understand a little bit about that change? But, if we go back to the 24 year old Shawn who was convicted of this crime, what kind of person was that? Can you describe that person?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: 24 years ago…

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Or if you can think of yourself as you were escorted through those gates?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I didn't have the wisdom I have now. I was still off in the, I'm going to say, the stupid things. I mean, I wasn't a, I probably smoked a little weed back then when I was escorted through the gates. Get write-ups. Not caring what the free man or the security guard would say or do. I was, I'm going to say, rebellious. I wasn't rebellious, I mean, I was hard-headed I would say. I was hard-headed. I didn't care because I had a life-sentence so whatever they threw at me, I was going to accept it or not accept it and deal with the consequences.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you find yourself getting into fights when you first got here?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: No, I never, never had no trouble.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How is Angola different today than when you first came here? A lot of folks talk about, some of them being here in the 80's and they talk about how it's changed.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah. I got here in the 90's. You work a little harder. You had a little more respect for each other. That's about, I mean, I think that's about it. I mean, I don't, yeah. I'd say that's about it. I could go on and on about certain things and vent, but it's a waste of time. It's a waste of time, I mean. Security's a whole lot easier-going now, they don't harass you, I mean. Besides, mostly women working here now anyways.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, sure. So, how different are you now from that person? You said that you are wiser.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That you are less rebellious.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Oh, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How else are you different?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I isolate myself now. I don't, I'm going to say I make my world small, which means I don't communicate with too many of them. I'm either going to the hobby shop, trying to do my little hobby craft, reading my Bible, or exercising. So, I try to have as little communication with too many people so, I just kind of.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Don't get me wrong, a whole bunch of people know me. I respect everybody, but like I said, I just, I try to make my world a little small, so I can say, "Okay, I don't need to be bothered with this person. I don't need to be bothered with that person. I don't feel like listening to this one here, talking about all these other people." It's just, so I made my world small, and it's just, I like it like that. So like I said, I go to the hobby shop, go to the gym, work out, go to the yard, run the yard.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, that's your typical day here? Between the hobby shop and …

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What organizations are you involved with or have been involved with since you been here?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: None.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I don't, I've seen the way they, the way some people. I wanted to, I would've liked to go into school. I was in school. I graduated from Auto mechanics. I would've liked to get into HVAC, which is learning about air conditioning and refrigeration. But now, it's just reentry now. So now, my hands are tired and I can't get in that. Like I said, all I do is go to work when they have work. But other than that, hobby shop.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What work?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I work in the clothing room. I load trucks for the clothing room.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. Have you been doing that for a long time?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: A couple of years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. What were you doing before that?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I worked for a colonel. We just, I did his paperwork and.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So the HVAC training is something that you are interested in doing, but because it's predominately for reentry folks, there's no room for people serving a life sentence?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Right, yeah. I would have liked to get on it. My thing is this here. I have an uncle that knows somebody, that knows somebody. They trying to get me out of here. I have my pardon papers put in, so I'm waiting to hear back on that.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: So I said well, if I'm going to do this, then let me learn something that I can make a lot of money fast, because I'm at an age now where I can't extend my life, to where, I've got a short window so say, I don't got but so many years to work and to accumulate enough money to where, it's going to take me through to, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Many people go through transformations, whether they're in prison or not, as they grow older. Sometimes when people make the changes to better their lives, it's because they just get tired of the way they were doing things before, or sometimes it's a lightbulb thing that goes off. It could be a person, mentor, something. How was the change for you? Would you say it's just getting older?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah, yeah. You're not off in the foolishness no more. You can see where a bunch of them are going to run into a wreck sooner or later. So you try to avoid all that, you say, "I've been there, done that," so leave it alone.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, so what advice do you have for a young man coming in with a life sentence? They come to you and say, "Shawn, I'm lost here. I just got here, can you help me out?" Can you tell me, what advice would you give that person?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Could I point them in the right direction? I'd say, man, get, I guess, get all the education you can. Leave the knuckleheads alone, and sooner or later you're going to figure out which ones they are, I can't, it's hard to tell someone, "Hey, don't do that," unless they experience it themselves then they understand why you said, "Don't do that," Because until they experience it themselves, they don't know,

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, I am going to ask you a little bit about your feelings about the crime you are convicted of.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When you look back, it's been, 25 years is a long time.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yes, it is.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: To get away from it. But at the same time, you are reminded every day that you are being punished for it.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yes, I am.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When you think back on the crime and the victim, victims, how do you feel about it now?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I get upset, like I said. I get upset being with somebody. You got to understand, if you go to my crime, you would see that I wasn't the one that killed this person. I was there. And, I can't lie, I was there, I know what happened, I did hit the guy. It was at a bar. But, as far as killing the guy, they know who killed him, he took his charge. He did tell them that, "Hey, I'm the one that killed him.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: All Shawn did was take the money.", so, he was, he was on the side. I don't, like I told him. I don't, I don't blame you. I know I was there. I blame myself for being there. So, that's where I'm at now, as far as this crime goes. I wish I could talk to the people and say, "I'm sorry for your son or your brother dying," but 25 years is a long time.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah it's one of the things that's been very clear in this project that there is a very wide breath of offenses for which people are serving a life sentence. All the way from someone like yourself, someone driving a car to a robbery that goes bad, to somebody that commits the most heinous thing you can think of. All with the same punishment, without distinction.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What do you think about that?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: 25 years. I understand now that, whatever happens, don't surprise me. I mean, it's just. I accept my responsibility for what happened. I thank God that I'm not in a little cell where the walls close in on you. At least I do have opportunity to move around, at time.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What's the worst part about this place? What's the worst part of the punishment for you?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: The worst part. Not being able to get out.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, and so, this is also a difficult question, when I understand the need to maintain hope...

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Oh, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: But, there must be times when you are forced to reckon with the likelihood that you may never leave here, and how do you handle that? How do you make sense of that?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: It never hit me yet.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Why do you think it hasn't hit you?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I guess because I still got hope.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you see guys who just give up hope? Guys who just come to accept that they are going to die here.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: No. I mean, I think if they accepted it, they probably would have lost their minds already and done something stupid to go sit in a cell. But as for them giving up hope. I live in a trustee dorm, they always have a little hope. I mean with the administration they have now, they saying, "Hey, we might be able to get a pardon or who knows." There is still hope.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you think it's sort of a survival mechanism?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Hope?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah, I guess it is.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, let's get through this scenario. Let's say you get a hearing before the pardon board.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You will have a short window of time to present your case. What do you want them to know about you, and why should they take a chance on you?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: My short window to explain to a pardon board. I could tell them where I was from, where I'm at now, and where I'm going. I have a jobs that's waiting on me. They have my record to say, "Hey, we see where Shawn was and possibly where he's going." I don't know. I'd have to sit there and talk to them face-to-face, I don't review anything as far as saying what you're going to tell them. I'll wing it whenever the time is right, I'll ask them for mercy?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Have you forgiven yourself?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Oh, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you think the guys who are serving a shorter sentence maybe don't have as much of an incentive to turn their lives around? It seems to me that the guys who have the longest sentences, including life sentences, seem to go to the greatest lengths to change their lives, to get more training, vocational training, albeit with the understanding that they might not be able to get out.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And the guys with shortened sentences may not. Do you think it's something to do with the lengths of the sentence?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I don't think so. I think, once you get to a certain age, if you didn't experience learning when you were in school, I think when you get into a certain age, as we do in here, you want to learn. That's when wisdom comes in. You want to learn everything you can, while you can, I guess, about different things. There's plenty, plenty of guys down the ward that all they do is study.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Whether it be the Bible or schools they're in, or schools they want to get into, they come to the library and get books on different, different things. They learning. I guess, this opens your mind, like a sponge, you want to get all the knowledge you can, I guess. You're a professor? How does it feel?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Feel pretty lucky. Yeah. Are you reading something right now?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: As far as, I got a sign language book in there that I look at every once in a while. But, my thing is the history of the Church, the Bible.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. Of all the things that you've done, we all have things that we are not proud of and we all have things that we are proud of. What are you proud of?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: What am I proud of, making it this long, I guess. Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, one fella told me that he's proud that he maintained his sanity.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I could see that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, tell me a little bit about the goals you have for the future? You referred to them briefly when you talked about the pardon board. What are your goals for the next 10, 20 years?

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: My goals are to, like I said, I have a couple of jobs waiting on me. If I was to get out, try to make as much money as I could. Maybe get a wife. Do I want kids? I think I'm at the age now where I might be a little too old for that now. But, just live the rest of my life.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, part of this project is to educate people about the reality of what life without parole actually means for people. Is there something that I should've asked you that I didn't ask you, that I didn't give you the opportunity to talk about that you think it'd be important for people to know.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I like to say, there's, I guess, there's a lot of things I'd like to tell the young ones that are trying to beat the doors down to come in here. That it's just not worth it. I mean, I don't know what society is now, I can't say, "Oh, it'll be better later." I mean, from what the news tells me, everybody 16 on up is on video games or on, popping pills or on heroin or going out all the time. Trying to shoot each other.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: I don't know what their goals are, if they have any. Like I said, I was that age at one time and, like I told you, I didn't have no goals. I didn't understand going to work. Supporting myself. Getting a house or trying build towards a house or having a wife and kids. That's something I didn't understand when I was growing up. Now that I stopped, now that my life stopped, that I could see and say, "Oh, I want that now." I don't know what to tell them

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. It makes sense.

transcript.speaker: Shawn
transcript.content: Yeah.
